issues.title: Typo of the draf title
issues.author: YuChaode
issues.body: The title of current 00 version missed a 'Y' at the beginning.

comments.author: tanyanxia
comments.body: This issue has been resolved.

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body: Solved in [draft-tan-ccamp-fgotn-yang-01](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-tan-ccamp-fgotn-yang-01)

issues.title: How to filter the termination points which can support fgOTN?
issues.author: YuChaode
issues.body:
The orginal design was to define a supported-fgotn-tp attribute which is used to indicate whether this termination point can support fgOTN or not. In the meeting 20250305, people agree to make some extension on encoding and switching-capability instead.
The problem is which attribute shall we choose, and how to make this extension and align with gmpls protocol.

comments.author: YuChaode
comments.body: we suggest to have one more expert from gmpls protocol to join this discussion.

comments.author: YuChaode
comments.body: the extension should be defined in our fgOTN draft instead to define it in TE type or layer1 types draft.

comments.author: YuChaode
comments.body:
2025-03-12: the question we found on today's meeting is why we need to provide this filtering functionality on TP instead of TTP. 
Dr.Tan will summarize the workflow between MDSC and PNC to make us clear what the requirement is.

issues.title: A deep analysis for hitless resizing
issues.author: YuChaode
issues.body:
It is suggested to have a deep analysis on the scenarios on hitless resizing, taking account of the interactions between data plane and control plane protocols.
For single domain service, the solution seems simpler, but it is worthwhile having some description.
For inter-domain service, it is worthwhile to investigate in detail.

issues.title: a summary of presentation slide of April interim meeting
issues.author: YuChaode
issues.body:
After IETF121, we have discussed the following iterms:
1. summary of the changes: some small changes on the model and draft.
2. open discussion:
1). we discussed how to define a generic structure to support multi-layers path; (conclusion has not been reached. We found it is a generic requirement, not only for fgOTN, but also for the other layers. we can describe the current standard solution and our concerns, and provide two options: extension on the dependancy tunnel, and extension on the path element. )
2). we have discussed how to filer the TP which can support fgOTN. The current solution in our draft is one extension attribute under the termination poin.(fgOTN-supported?) We didn't make agreement on this solution. And one possible solution is to make some extension on switching-capability and encoding. But there could be some impact on PCEP and GMPLS protocol, we would like to seek some helps from the experts on this domain. Maybe we need to have some collaboration with Lin Yi's draft and it seems that we need a new signal type.
3). We have discussed the link's bandwidth which can support fgOTN. (picture and example are needed.)
raised WG adoption request in this meeting.

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body: Closed with: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/slides-interim-2025-ccamp-03-sessa-5-yang-data-models-for-fine-grain-optical-transport-network/

issues.title: Switching and LSP encoding types for fgOTN
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body:
Need to discuss whether the same switching and LSP encoding types can be used for ODUk and fgODUflex and therefore only a new odu-type value shall be defined for fgODUflex.

The text describing the fgOTN topology and tunnel models can be updated accordingly.

_Originally posted by @italobusi in https://github.com/YuChaode/draft-tan-ccamp-fgotn-yang/pull/3#discussion_r2025703759_

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
The offline suggestion from GMPLS/PCEP experts is to use the existing switching and LSP encoding types and to define a new signal type (in GMPLS/PCEP) or odu-type (in YANG) for fgODUflex

To further investigate where this new odu-type can be defined:
1. In a new `fgotn-types` YANG module within this draft
2. In an RFC-bis for layer1-types 

Note that https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-ccamp-layer1-types is in the RFC Editors Queue so it it too late to update it before it is published as an RFC

Next steps:
1. Investigate the impact of defining a new odu-type with the existing OTN topology and OTN tunnel model
1. Check with CCAMP and PCEP mailing lists that the proposed approach is agreed for GMPLS, PCEP and YANG
1. Decide where to define the new odu-type identity

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body: - [ ] Invite Lin Yi and evaluate the impact of defining a new odu-type with the existing OTN topology and OTN tunnel model

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
The signal type (in GMPLS/PCEP) or odu-type (in YANG) have been defined to distinguish between different types of ODUk (e.g., ODU0, ODU2, ODU4) which are using the same switching and LSP encoding types (ODUk)

If new (fgODUflex) switching and LSP encoding types are defined for fgODUflex, there is no need to define a new odu-type. The fgODUflex are uniquely identified using the new (fgODUflex) switching and LSP encoding types

If, instead, the existing (ODUk) switching and LSP encoding types are re-used for fgODUflex, then there is a need to define a new odu-type to distinguish fgODUflex from other types of ODUk (e.g., ODU0, ODU2, ODU4)

I am also wondering whether there are some implications on the choice, especially when considering multi-layer relationship between fgOTN and OTN

If new (fgODUflex) switching and LSP encoding types, the multi-layer relationship between fgOTN and OTN would be the same as the multi-layer relationship between OTN and WDM

I am not sure this solution would not conflict with the current fgOTN topology YANG model extensions **(I can investigate further)**

If a new fgODUflex odu-type is defined, the multi-layer relationship between fgODUflex and ODUk would be the same as the multi-layer relationship between LO-ODU and HO-ODU

I am not sure this solution would not conflict with the current fgOTN topology YANG model extensions **(I can investigate further)**

Considering the current fgOTN topology YANG model, I am wondering whether it is better not to define neither new (fgODUflex) switching and LSP encoding types nor a new fgODUflex odu-type.

The only doubt I have in this case is about how to setup an fgODUflex tunnel.

One option is to define a new choice can be defined for fgODUflex tunnels:

```
  augment /te:te/te:globals/te:named-path-constraints/te:named-path-constraint/te:te-bandwidth/te:technology:
    +--:(fgotn)
       +--rw fgoduflex-bandwidth?       string
```

With this approach and the supported-fgotn-tp, there is no need to define new (fgODUflex) switching and LSP encoding types nor new fgODUflex odu-type (on both TP and TTP objects), avoiding any impact on existing TE and OTN topology models

issues.title: The format of bandwidth odu-ts-number and fgOTN-bandwidth
issues.author: YuChaode
issues.body: Currently, these two attributes are defined as string format. But there are some suggestions to use integer or decimal to represent.

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
Call on 2025-05-23

Agreed to change these attributes to integer

issues.title: Clean up the content of path splicing scenario's description
issues.author: YuChaode
issues.body: The original motivation is to describe the requirement of multi-layers path, but it is coupled with protection scenario. Some cleanup is needed for the "Multi-layer Path Splicing Scenario of fgOTN" section.

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
**2025-06-18 Call**

There is some overlapping between the content of section 2.1 (Retrieve Server Tunnels Scenario of fgOTN) and the content of section 2.2 (Multi-layer Path Splicing Scenario of fgOTN)

Need to consider some restructuring of the content between these two sections (e.g., merging the two scenarios)

Section 2.1 is describing the need to setup one or more sever layer ODUk tunnels before setting up an fgODUflex tunnel. This requirements is applicable to any type of fgODUflex tunnel (protected or unprotected)

Section 2.2 is focusing on the need to setup an fgODUflex tunnel with a primary path and a secondary path to provide protection

The need to setup one or more sever layer ODUk tunnels before setting up an fgODUflex tunnel is independent from the need to provide protection

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body: - [x] Review the text in section 2.1 and section 2.2 of draft-tan-ccamp-fgotn-yang-04

issues.title: Discuss with ITU-T on the inter-domain fgOTN tunnel bandwidth modification
issues.author: YuChaode
issues.body:
On the meeting 20250430, we discussed the scenario of inter-domain fgOTN service bandwidth modification. We have a concern on the scenario that there could be a failure on the single direction while it is successful on the other direction. There should be some rollback on the device perspective and the orchestrator needs to send a bandiwidth modification to change it back.
we suggested to solidate it at first on our draft, and write a contribution to ITU-T SG15 Q11 & Q14, to check whether our solution is acceptable in ITU-T. So that we can have a same understanding on this scenario.

issues.title: Overlapping between section 2.1 and section 2.2
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body:
There is some overlapping between the content of section 2.1 (Retrieve Server Tunnels Scenario of fgOTN) and the content of section 2.2 (Multi-layer Path Splicing Scenario of fgOTN)

Need to consider some restructuring of the content between these two sections (e.g., merging the two scenarios)

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
Section 2.1 is describing the need to setup one or more sever layer ODUk tunnels before setting up an fgODUflex tunnel. This requirements is applicable to any type of fgODUflex tunnel (protected or unprotected)

Section 2.2 is focusing on the need to setup an fgODUflex tunnel with a primary path and a secondary path to provide protection

The need to setup one or more sever layer ODUk tunnels before setting up an fgODUflex tunnel is independent from the need to provide protection

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body: Duplicated with #9

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
Section 2.2 is describing the multi-layer path setup and should be finalized with PR #23 

Section 2.1 should focus on the multi-layer topology discovering and should be finalized after completing the discussion on fgOTN topology

issues.title: Implications for defining new switching and LSP encoding types for fgOTN
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body: Check the impacts on existing TE and OTN topology and tunnel models if new switching and LSP encoding types for fgOTN are defined instead of re-using the existing ODUk switching and LSP encoding types

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
The existing ODU encoding and switching-type provides sufficient information to identify OTN links and LTPs:
- the bandwidth of an OTN link provides sufficient information to identify whether the OTN link supports or not fgOTN
- the `supported-fgotn-tp` or, alternatively, the type of terminated OTN link provides sufficient information to identify whether the OTN TP supports or not fgOTN

As a consequence, defining a new fgODU encoding and switching-type would create a potential conflict with the existing use of encoding and switching-type for links and TPs.

More discussion is needed on the identification of fgOTN TTPs and tunnels.

comments.author: tanyanxia
comments.body:
Since the MDSC coordinator does not maintain TTP information and src-ttp-id and dst-ttp-id are also not need to send to the controller when building tunnels in our current network.  When querying tunnels, the controller needs to support returning TTP.

Moreover, it has been confirmed in the fgOTN draft that we will not define a new network type for fgOTN.

Based on previous discussions, adding new switching and LSP encoding types for fgOTN may affect the existing TE and OTN topology and tunnel models.

For these reasons, we think there is no need to adding new switching and LSP encoding types for fgOTN to confirm that the current TTP is a termination point of an fgOTN tunnel.

I think we only need to define a new fgODUflex odu-type to identify whether it is a fgOTN tunnel.
@italobusi

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
**2025-11-19 Call**

Agreed not to define a new switching and LSP encoding types for fgOTN

Regarding the need to define a new odu-type for fgOTN, see: https://github.com/YuChaode/draft-tan-ccamp-fgotn-yang/issues/13#issuecomment-3552982291

issues.title: Implications for defining new ODU type for fgOTN
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body: Check the impacts on existing OTN topology and tunnel models if a new ODU type for fgOTN is defined, re-using the existing ODUk switching and LSP encoding types

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
**2025-11-19 Call**

Defining a new odu-type for fgOTN would have an impact on the definition of OTN bandwidth in the topology model

For example, the fgOTN odu-type shall not be used in the odutlist defined under the max-link-bandwidth:

```
  augment /nw:networks/nw:network/nt:link/tet:te
            /tet:te-link-attributes/tet:max-link-bandwidth
            /tet:te-bandwidth:
    +--rw otn-bandwidth
       +--rw odulist* [odu-type]
       |  +--rw odu-type     identityref
       |  +--rw number?      uint16
       |  +--rw ts-number?   uint16
       +--rw fgotn-bandwidth?   uint16
```

Note: wait for resolution of issue #14

comments.author: italobusi

issues.title: Implications for not defining new ODU, switching and LSP encoding types for fgOTN
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body: Check how the fgOTN topology and tunnel models can work re-using the existing ODUk switching and LSP encoding types for fgOTN and without defining new ODU type for fgODUflex

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
**2025-11-19 Call**

Without defining new ODU, switching and LSP encoding types for fgOTN, there is a need to define something else to identify fgOTN tunnels.

Since the OTN tunnel is still work-in-progress, one solution could be to define a new odu-tunnel-type base (with ODUflex, ODU0, ODU1, ODU2, ODU2e, ODU3, ODU4) to be used only in the OTN tunnel model (instead of the odu-type as currently defined), to identify whether the OTN tunnel is an e.g., ODU0, ODU1 tunnel.

Note: for the issues of re-suing the odu-type for fgOTN, see: https://github.com/YuChaode/draft-tan-ccamp-fgotn-yang/issues/13#issuecomment-3552982291

A new odu-tunnel-type can then be defined to identify whether the OTN tunnel is an fgOTN tunnels

OLD

```
  augment /te:te/te:globals/te:named-path-constraints
            /te:named-path-constraint/te:te-bandwidth/te:technology:
    +--:(otn)
       +--rw otn-bandwidth
          +--rw odu-type?                     identityref    // base odu-type (ODUflex, ODU0, ODU1, ..., ODU4)
          +--rw (oduflex-type)?
             ...

```

NEW

```
  augment /te:te/te:globals/te:named-path-constraints
            /te:named-path-constraint/te:te-bandwidth/te:technology:
    +--:(otn)
       +--rw otn-bandwidth
          +--rw odu-type?                     identityref    // base odu-tunnel-type (ODUflex, ODU0, ODU1, ..., ODU4, fgODUflex)
          +--rw (oduflex-type)?
             ...
```

- [ ] @tanyanxia check whether this approach is ok for supporting fgOTN tunnels

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
The solution does not work because the OTN path bandwidth is defined in layer1-types which is in RFC Editor Queue:

```
  grouping otn-path-bandwidth:
    +-- otn-bandwidth
       +-- odu-type?                     identityref
       +-- (oduflex-type)?                // when odu-type is ODUflex/ODUflex-resizable
          ...
```

Therefore it seems that for supporting fgOTN tunnel, a new odu-type for fgODUflex needs to be defined

An alternative solution could be not to use the otn-path-bandwidth grouping for fgOTN tunnel bandwidth and define a new case:

```
  augment /te:te/te:tunnels/te:tunnel/te:te-bandwidth/te:technology:
    +--:(fg-otn)
       +--rw fgotn-bandwidth?   uint16
```

issues.title: Measurement unit for fgotn-bandwidth
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body:
The I-D text mentions that the fgotn-bandwidth is expressed in Mbps but there is no units statement in YANG

Moreover, Mbps is sometimes ambiguous (megabits or megabytes), so it is better to expand. Following RFC8776-bis convention, we can add the following statement in YANG:

```
   units "megabits per second";
```

In alternative, we can use the bandwidth-mbps data type defined in RFC8776-bis

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
**2025-09-03**

Agreed to add the units as "megabits per second"

issues.title: Revert changes in section 3
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body: The text of section 3 in the -04 version needs to be changed back to the text in the -03 version

issues.title: Check the LSP state to be reported during the bandwidth resizing
issues.author: italobusi

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
You are correct, there is no LSP state defined in RFC8776-bis to report that bandwidth resizing is in-progress, so we need to define new LSP states.

I have only one doubt: do we need to define a new 'ietf-te-types:lsp-path-modified' LSP state or could we re-use the exiting 'ietf-te-types:lsp-state-up'?

Few questions:
1. Should we rename the `ietf-te-types:lsp-path-modifying` to something different (e.g., `ietf-te-types:lsp-state-modifying`) since we are not modifying the LSP path but only its bandwidth?
1. Should we rename the `ietf-te-types:lsp-path-modified` to something different (e.g., `ietf-te-types:lsp-state-modified-ok`) since we are not modifying the LSP path but only its bandwidth and we might need also an LSP state to report the modification failure?

comments.author: tanyanxia
comments.body: We should define ietf-te-types:lsp-bandwidth-modified-ok and ietf-te-types:lsp-bandwidth-modify-failed in the RFC 8776.

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
Looking at RFC 8776, I am still having a doubt about the need to add also the ietf-te-types:lsp-bandwidth-modifying state

For LSP path setup, the following three states are defined in RFC 8776:
- lsp-state-setting-up
- lsp-state-setup-ok
- lsp-state-setup-failed

It is not fully clear to me when the LSP state can/should transition to lsp-state-up: I will check with the co-authors of RFC 8776

Similar states are defined for the path computation phase:
- lsp-path-computing
- lsp-path-computation-ok
- lsp-path-computation-failed

Consistently, I think the following states can be defined for LSP bandwidth modification:
- lsp-bandwidth-modifying
- lsp-bandwidth-modify-failed
- lsp-bandwidth-modified-ok

For the time being, we can be silent about the transition from lsp-bandwidth-modified-ok to lsp-state-up until we have clarified what happens during LSP setup

comments.author: tanyanxia
comments.body: I agree to add the "lsp-bandwidth-modifying" state, ensuring it aligns with LSP path setup and LSP path computation.

issues.title: Which controller shall report the completion of resizing procedure
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body:
The current text assumes that controller 1 reports when the resizing procedure in the forward direction is completed and controller 3 reports when the resizing procedure in the reverse direction is completed

Need to check whether it is possible for controller 1 to report when the resizing procedure in both directions is completed

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
It is worth being more clear and explicit about what conditions are reported by the controllers

The conditions when the source or sink node starts and exits the unidirectional resizing protocol are defined in annex O of ITU-T G.709 (see for example Figure O.2 and Figure O.2)

In case of bidirectional connections, two independent resizing protocols need to run in the forward and reverse direction.

Node 1 is the source node for the resizing protocol in the forward direction and the sink node for the resizing protocol in the reverse direction. After it exits both resizing protocols in the forward and in the reverse direction, it can report to controller 1 that the bidirectional resizing procedure has been terminated.

issues.body: Needs to analyze failure scenarios during hitless resizing: how they are detected and reported to the MDSC?


Update the definition of the unreserved-bandwidth in the YANG data model as follow:

```
  augment /nw:networks/nw:network/nt:link/tet:te
            /tet:te-link-attributes/tet:unreserved-bandwidth
            /tet:te-bandwidth/otnt:otn-bandwidth:

    +--rw fgotnlist* [odu-type odu-ts-number]

```

Update the definition of the otn-label-range in the YANG data model as follow:

```
  augment /nw:networks/tet:te/tet:templates/tet:link-template
            /tet:te-link-attributes/tet:label-restrictions
            /tet:label-restriction/otnt:otn-label-range:
    +--rw fgts-range* [odu-type odu-ts-number]
       +--rw odu-type           identityref
       +--rw odu-ts-number      string
       +--rw fgts-reserved?     string
       +--rw fgts-unreserved?   string

```

issues.title: JSON examples for fgOTN topology
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body: Prepare some JSON examples of the fgOTN topology model Reference network: Where: - node NE1, NE2, and NE4 support fgOTN switching, node NE3 does not support fgOTN - all the links are OTU2 links - on the link between NE1 and NE2 there is only one ODU1 server layer tunnel - on the link between NE2 and NE4 there are two ODU0 server layer tunnels - between NE1 and NE4 an ODU1 server layer tunnel is setup (through the NE1-NE3-NE4)

pulls.title: Changes provided by China Unicom for IETF 121
pulls.author: italobusi

pulls.title: update the draft and models for 02 version
pulls.author: YuChaode

comments.body:
```suggestion
    seriesinfo: ITU-T Recommendation G.709.20
```

The management of TE interfaces is outside the scope of a network model (see also the text in OTN tunnel model):

```suggestion
This document presents the control interface requirements of fgOTN, and defines two YANG data models for fgOTN topology and fgOTN tunnel. The topology model can capture topological and resource-related information pertaining to fgOTN. The fgOTN tunnel YANG data model defined in this document is used for the provisioning and management of fgOTN Traffic Engineering (TE) tunnels and Label Switched Paths (LSPs).
```

I would remove the term 'dependency' at least for the time being. I would also add some node names and show, as an example, and ODU0 server layer tunnel from node X to node Y, fgOTN switching in node Y and another ODU2 server layer tunnel in node Z

I do not understand why the requirement to represent the ODU server layer tunnel is coupled with the protection.

Why this is not required for unprotected services/fgODUflex connections?

The sentence is too long and hard to read. I would suggest to split (also considering some bullets)

The support of hitless resizing, especially in multi-domain scenarios, requires some deep investigation on how control plane and data plane protocol interacts each other.
The sentence is not fully clear to me. Let's discuss how to rephrase it.
why "Node Augmentation" and not "Termination Point Augmentation"?
I think we need to describe the relationship between this attribute and the interface-switching-capability of this TP and of the Links terminated on this TP.
Why it is a string and not a integer or decimal type? It can be an integer/decimal with Mbps unit (e.g., 2500) or also an integer representing the number of ODU0s (e.g., 2)

Dr.Tan will modify the description. The requirement is to provide multi-layer path object in the LSP, there is no relationship with protection.
There could be two examples attached in the appendix for 1+1 protection and unprotected service.
Dr.Tan will help to simplify this paragraph. And for the hitless resizing comment, we have create an issue to trace.

TODO: Italo will help to rephrase this sentence. 
The meaning of this sentence is to illustrate the usage of YANG data model. The fgOTN topology should not be a seperated network topology while fgOTN tunnel could be a new of ODU layer.
We still need to have a discussion on Issue #4 to identify what we need to make this augmentation, after that we can update the title.
See issue #4 .
Dr.Zheng and Dr.Tan will have a discussion after the meeting and make a decision. We can discuss it in the next meeting.

@tanyanxia @YuChaode : what about the following rephrasing?

```suggestion
In order to provide fgOTN capabilities, this document defines two YANG data models augmenting the OTN topology and the OTN tunnel YANG data models, as defined in {{!I-D.ietf-ccamp-otn-topo-yang}} and {{!I-D.ietf-ccamp-otn-tunnel-model}}.

As defined in Annex M of {{ITU-T_G.709}}, fgOTN is defining a new path layer network which complements the existing OTN. Therefore:

- A single network topology instance is used to report both OTN and fgOTN topology information: fgOTN technology-specific attributes are therefore defined in the fgOTN topology model as augmentations of the OTN topology model, but without defining a new network type for fgOTN.

- The OTN tunnel model can be used to setup either an OTN or an fgOTN tunnel: fgOTN technology-specific attributes are therefore defined in the fgOTN tunnel model as augmentations of the OTN tunnel model, which are applicable only when the OTN tunnel is an fgOTN tunnel.
```

I would like to describe that the same switching-type and encoding types can be used for ODUk and fgODUflex and therefore that a new odu-type value shall be defined by I think it is too early. We can update this text when we have agreed on this point

The change agreed in https://github.com/YuChaode/draft-tan-ccamp-fgotn-yang/pull/3#discussion_r1980034578 has been lost:

```suggestion
This document defines YANG data models to describe the topology and tunnel information of a fine grain Optical Transport Network. The YANG data models defined in this document are designed to meet the requirements for efficient transmission of sub-1G client signals in transport network.
```
Resolved with https://github.com/YuChaode/draft-tan-ccamp-fgotn-yang/pull/3/commits/5c385ec3f312ea76c8186e3dbc9c9592ee72cac1

The section title has been properly updated but the description and figure is still bound to the protection configuration.

I would suggest to keep the text as it is for the v02 update to present at the April 10, 2025 interim meeting and create a new issue to track the need improve this description
Resolved with https://github.com/YuChaode/draft-tan-ccamp-fgotn-yang/pull/3/commits/5c385ec3f312ea76c8186e3dbc9c9592ee72cac1
Resolved with https://github.com/YuChaode/draft-tan-ccamp-fgotn-yang/pull/3/commits/5c385ec3f312ea76c8186e3dbc9c9592ee72cac1
I would suggest to keep the string type in the v02 update to present at the April 10, 2025 interim meeting and create a new issue to track the need to further discuss this data type.

Kramdown syntax:

```suggestion
{{fig-multiplexing scenario}} below shows an example of scenario to retrieve server tunnels for multi-domain fgOTN service. In this example, some small bandwidth fgOTN service are aggregated by the access ring (10G), and then aggregated into a bigger bandwidth in metro ring (100G). The allocation of TS to support fgOTN switching maybe different in access ring and metro ring. E.g. there could be three ODU0 allocated in the access ring while there could be two ODU2 are allocated in the metro ring to support fgOTN switching. In this example, the server layer ODUk tunnel for fgOTN tunnel from node A to node E is ODU0, and the server layer tunnel from node E to node G is ODU2. The server layer tunnel for fgOTN tunnel will include one ODU0 tunnel and one ODU2 tunnel.
```

Kramdown syntax and alignment of the names of the nodes:

```suggestion
Not all nodes in the operator network support fgOTN, as shown in {{fig-service protection}}, node N-f5 and node N-f6 do not support fgOTN. To present the end-to-end primary-path and secondary-path of the services on the client side, it is necessary to complete the end-to-end path splicing based on the the ODU tunnel information associated with the fgotn tunnel.
```

Kramdown syntax:

```suggestion
Multi-domain hitless resizing should be supported. In the case of hitless resizing within a single domain, the "explicit route object" structure is not required. However, for multi-domain hitless resizing scenario, it is necessary to specify the ODUk TS and fgts numbers information on the ports of cross domain nodes in "explicit route objects" structure. For example, node 2 and node 3 in {{fig-hitless resizing}}. When there are multiple cross domain fgOTN service hitless resizing, the MDSC coordinator needs to issue the service resizing instructions to the domain controllers where the service source and destination are located separately.
```

```suggestion
This document presents the control interface requirements of fgOTN, and defines two YANG data models for fgOTN topology and fgOTN tunnel. The topology model can capture topological and resource-related information pertaining to fgOTN. The fgOTN tunnel YANG data model defined in this document is used for the provisioning and management of fgOTN Traffic Engineering (TE) tunnels and Label Switched Paths (LSPs).
```
To be discussed later
The comment is tracked by the issue #9

comments.body: Need more discussion for section 2.1
See the comment above about adding a pattern to the string or defining a common data type for ts-list

I am wondering whether the augment target above is correct:

```
  augment "/nw:networks/tet:te/tet:templates/tet:link-template"+ 
          "/tet:te-link-attributes/tet:label-restrictions" +
          "/tet:label-restriction/otnt:otn-label-range" {
```

I am wondering whether it should be:

```
  augment "/nw:networks/nw:network/nt:link/tet:te" + 
          "/tet:te-link-attributes/tet:label-restrictions" +
          "/tet:label-restriction/otnt:otn-label-range" {
```

```suggestion
         is set up";
```
